meanings.definition: Make (guilt or an offense) seem less serious or more forgivable.
meanings.sent1: She tried to extenuate her mistake by explaining the circumstances.
meanings.sent2: He always tries to extenuate his actions when he knows he's wrong.
meanings.sent3: The way he tried to extenuate his lie was so obvious, it made everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: Her apology did little to extenuate the hurt she caused.
meanings.sent5: The lawyer's job is to extenuate the crimes of their clients.

meanings.sent1: The illness began to extenuate his once muscular frame.
meanings.sent2: The strict diet seemed to extenuate her figure more than she expected.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to extenuate himself for skipping meals was met with concern from his friends.
meanings.sent4: The intense training regimen threatened to extenuate the athletes beyond recognition.
meanings.sent5: The prolonged famine continued to extenuate the population, leaving them weak and frail.
